Table of Contents

Enum NotificationType

Namespace
NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums
Assembly
NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll

Specifies the delivery/presentation method for notifications in the RSS reader application.

public enum NotificationType

Fields

Banner = 4

Prominent visual banner (heads-up, persistent, or expanded style), typically without sound unless combined with priority.

Typical use cases:

  • High-priority events requiring stronger visual emphasis
  • Notifications that should remain visible longer than a standard toast
  • Critical alerts on platforms that distinguish banner styles

Behavior:

  • Displays as a larger, more noticeable banner/pop-up (may cover more screen area or persist longer)
  • No automatic sound (sound controlled separately via NotificationPriority)
  • Often used for elevated-attention but non-audible alerts
Both = 2

Both visual notification (toast/banner) and audible alert (sound/vibration).

Typical use cases:

  • Standard new article notifications when sound is enabled
  • Medium-to-high importance events that should catch attention
  • User's default preference for important feeds

Behavior:

  • Shows visual element + plays notification sound once
  • Most common and expected delivery method for alerting notifications
  • Combines visibility with immediate awareness
Silent = 3

No visual or audible interruption — notification is logged internally only.

Typical use cases:

  • Successful background operations (sync completed, feed refreshed silently)
  • Debug/telemetry events visible only in logs or app diagnostics
  • Events explicitly muted by user per category

Behavior:

  • No user-visible popup, banner, sound, or vibration
  • May still be recorded in an in-app notification history or activity log
  • Zero interruption to user experience
Sound = 1

Audible alert only (sound/vibration), without any visual element on screen.

Typical use cases:

  • Rare — mostly for very specific accessibility scenarios or legacy behaviors
  • Subtle reminders when user is already looking at the app

Behavior:

  • Plays sound (and possibly vibration) but shows nothing on screen
  • May not be supported or visible on all platforms (many require visual pairing with sound)
  • Use cautiously to avoid confusing or annoying users

Recommendation: Prefer Both or Toast in most cases.

Toast = 0

Visual notification only (toast-style popup or entry in notification center). No sound is played.

Typical use cases:

  • Low-to-normal priority new article notifications when user has disabled sounds
  • Informational messages that do not require immediate attention

Behavior:

  • Shows a brief toast or persistent notification entry
  • No audible alert
  • Respects mute/quiet modes fully

Remarks

This enumeration defines how a notification is delivered to the user — whether visually, audibly, both, or silently in the background — independent of its priority or content. It controls the immediate user experience at the moment of delivery.

NotificationType affects:

  • Whether a visual element (toast, banner, popup) is shown on screen
  • Whether a sound alert is played (regardless of device volume/mute state)
  • Whether the notification is completely silent and only logged internally
  • How intrusive the notification feels to the user at the time it is triggered

Important business rules and usage guidelines:

  • The type is typically chosen based on the event's nature and user-configured preferences for specific notification categories (new articles, feed errors, sync status, etc.).
  • Silent should be used for background/logging-only events that the user should never be interrupted for (e.g., successful background sync, minor housekeeping).
  • Sound alone (without visual) is rare and usually discouraged — most platforms require a visual component when playing sound for accessibility and UX reasons.
  • Banner is intended for more attention-grabbing visual presentation (larger, persistent, or heads-up style) compared to a standard Toast.
  • Final delivery may still be modulated by device settings (Do Not Disturb, notification channels, app-level mute, screen state), but NotificationType defines the application's intended delivery intent.
  • Default for most article-related notifications: Both or Toast (depending on user preference for sound).
